utterances: We're hoping to see it come down, but we're not holding our breath.
In fact, the Energy Department's Doug McIntyre(ph) says, diesel prices could go the other way.
Just as the end of the summer driving season brings some relief to the gasoline market, cooler fall weather has the opposite effect on diesel prices.
Diesel fuel is very similar to heating oil, so when demand for heating oil goes up, it usually also includes upward price pressure on diesel fuel.
Of course, both gasoline and diesel prices are subject to swings in the cost of crude oil.
Crude oil prices dropped almost $2.00 a barrel yesterday when forecasts said tropical storm Ernesto would probably steer clear of the oil-rich region of the Gulf Coast.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, San Diego.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Andrea Seabrook.

That was a tweet.

BUSH: Tomorrow I'm going down to Georgia and Alabama.

I go down knowing full well that I'll be seeing people whose lives were turned upside down by the tornadoes.
The government of Iraq is preparing for an expanded neighbors meeting, first at a sub-ministerial level, that will take place in Baghdad in the first half of March.
I'm pleased that the government of Iraq is launching this new diplomatic initiative and that we will be able to support it and participate in it.

I have accepted his resignation.

Yes.

That's hip-hop artist, Laramie Neg Ambarius(ph), encouraging his fellow Haitians to clean up the streets.
Laramie is one of the finalists in a competition sponsored by the group, Yele Haiti, a nonpolitical movement aimed at rebuilding the country.
The founder of Yele Haiti is the Haitian-born, Grammy-winning, hip-hop artist, Wyclef Jean.
He joins us now from his recording studio in Manhattan.
Hello.
Hello.
And if you want to talk with Wyclef Jean about Haiti, here your chance.
Give us a call.
Our number is 1-800-989-TALK.
The email address is talk@npr.org.
Mr.
Jean, first of all, what does Why-lay(ph)--No, you pronounce it.
You tell me the name of it.
You say it.
Okay, the name is Yele.
Y-E-L-E.
Yele.
Yele is like a slang that I came up with.
The actual word is called yile(ph).
Yile(ph) in Creole means "to yell.
So, when I slang it and say "yele," yele means "cry of freedom.
And why did you choose that name?
I mean, I chose the name "cry of freedom" because our people in our country, in Haiti, they're crying for freedom.
They just want to be free.
You know, you make a good point that Haiti is a country that, for so many years, has struggled with poverty, with violence, with political disarray.
Why do you think you can make a difference?

I mean, the reason why I think I could make a difference is because, you know, I read the books of Martin Luther King, Malcolm X, Marcus Garvey, Bob Marley, and etc. What happens is you can't save a nation, but you can save a few, and a few can make change.
Which means that one man inspired Wyclef, and as he was inspiring Wyclef, someone was telling him, how do you think you can make a difference?
He said, if I could instill this pride in one man, this man can go far.
So, all I have to do is instill this mission inside of one kid, and he'll take it further.
How old were you when you left Haiti?
I was 10 years old when I left the island.
Tell me about your life there before you left.
I lived in a place called La Ser(ph), and a small village in a place called Guadaboukier(ph).
And basically, I remember going to school.
Sometimes walking, because the roads was not done, you know what I mean?
Mm-hmm.
Puddle.
I remember when it rained so much, I would get on the back of a donkey and be taken to school.
But I remember that one thing that we always had, it's like no matter how poor we had, we always had celebration, and the hope that the future would be better.
No donkeys for you now, huh?
I still have donkeys in the mainland, you know.
I was going to say, not in Manhattan.
Well, it's illegal for you to have donkeys in Manhattan.
Now, you get arrested for that.
Oh, okay.
I'm just checking.
(Soundbite of laughter)
When you were growing up in Haiti, did you have it in your mind that at some point, you would come back?
I mean, I know that's a lot to put on a 10-year-old boy, but was that something that was part of your thought that I'm going to come back someday and I'm going to do something?
I mean, the whole idea for me was to be able to do something and go back and share it in my country.
My first success was with my group called The Fugees, and that was like in 1996, I'd say.
But the first CD that we put out, which was an awareness CD, you know, we was talking about the violence, what's going on in Haiti, and how we can change the situation.
Fugees, in part, meaning from refugeees.
